channel.title: [Question] Word Censors
channel.description:
I was wondering if anyone know where I can put my little simple word censor i coded.
I was thinking ChatHandler.Java but I dont want mess around with it unless I know for sure.
Im hoping someone would know.
Ty, Eli
P.S. (If this works... ILL RELEASE IT :P)

item.title: [Question] Word Censors
item.dc:creator: @pesterd pesterd
item.description:
@pesterd wrote:

[quote=“vortex, post:15, topic:280720”][quote author=meatstick link=topic=370774.msg2802429#msg2802429 date=1243529688]

But of course, having the words listed somewhere on the server-side would also be much simpler when it comes to managing them - if a list is used that is, but I doubt it - I guess a formula is used on the original RSC.

Oh and yes it was a list, someone dumped it from 202 client i think, don’t remember who.
[/quote]
At least I have done that but it’s quite easy anyway, all the bad words are stored in filters*.jag as just pure text. Easily dumped etc etc.

pesterd: deobfuscate a 204 client (classic.runescape.com/client2/mudclient204.jar) and compare it’s ChatHandler (no refactored obviously) and the one the client you use has, since the filters were removed from the base Reines released back then that everybody uses.[/quote]

I cant access runescape.com i get an apache error or something

If someone can send me the 204 mudclient I would appreciate it

Read full topic

item.title: [Question] Word Censors
item.dc:creator: @meatstick meatstick
item.description:
@meatstick wrote:

Here’s something i made quick:

[code]
class Test2 {

public static void main(String[] args) {
	String a = "i am not a fuckface";
	String[] b = { "fuck" }; 
	for(int i = 0; i < b.length; i++) {
		if(a.contains(b[i])) {
			System.out.println("Word '"+a+"' contained '"+b[i]+"'");
			a = a.replaceAll(b[i], replaceWithChars(b[i].length()));
		}
	}
	System.out.println(a);
}

public static String replaceWithChars(int len) {
	String newString = "";
	char c = '*';
	for(int i = 0; i < len; i++)
		newString += c;
	System.out.println(newString);
	return newString;
}

}[/code]
Output:

Word 'i am not a fuckface' contained 'fuck'
****
i am not a ****face

Read full topic

item.title: [Question] Word Censors
item.dc:creator: @PKERZ PKERZ
item.description:
@PKERZ wrote:

pesterd, doesn’t the client already have this feature already? Well, atleast a client without modifications does, and I would say, you could just ripp that and convert it into your client… Otherwise, somewhere close to the place where chat-messages will be displayed would be the place to put it, I assume… If you make your own method, then a method that returns a String would be good, and just use that method instead of the String that holds the message (or however it works) - but obviously you must have the String containing the chat-message as parameter-argument in that method.

Not sure if you understood what I ment, so here is an example:

Original - using example variable names:

display(chatMessage);

The modified one - using example variable names:

display(yourCustomChatMessageWordCensorMethod(chatMessage));

The custom method could look similar to this:

public final String yourCustomChatMessageWordCensorMethod(String chatMessage) { [... chat-message coversion code ...] return [modified chat-message]; }

Read full topic

item.title: [Question] Word Censors
item.dc:creator: @darscape darscape
item.description:
@darscape wrote:

Jagex did chat filtering client-side.

I remember this from when I used Reibot and would disable chat filtering. Could see other people swearing and swear back at them.

Jagex never seemed to be able to ban the word “bullass”

item.title: [Question] Word Censors
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

Personally i’d stick it in client, let the client do the processing of it instead of giving server extra load.

If someone uses a hacked client, bot or whatever who gives a shit if they can see bad words.

Read full topic

item.title: [Question] Word Censors
item.dc:creator: @PKERZ PKERZ
item.description:
@PKERZ wrote:

KO9, I wouldn’t say that rule really applies to this feature, because this feature isn’t as important as many others. If this feature was removed, the worst case-scenario would be that people could see the cuss-words etc (just like in the real RSC). Also, you must make up your mind about whether adding a not-so-important feature to the server, where the server will also have to go under more stress, or simply adding it to the client and let your clients computers handle the processing. But of course, having the words listed somewhere on the server-side would also be much simpler when it comes to managing them - if a list is used that is, but I doubt it - I guess a formula is used on the original RSC.

Read full topic

item.title: [Question] Word Censors
item.dc:creator: @KO9 KO9
item.description:
@KO9 wrote:

LLscape.net:

I found the easiest way to do it is client sided, for demonik based sources anyway. IDK about rscd, but I’d guess it’d be similar.

.

If you put it client side you may as well not put it in at all. Rule 1 of client<->server communication for games is never trust the client

Read full topic
